posts.cooked:
image 715×475 72.6 KB

image 715×475 72.6 KB

image 715×475 72.6 KB

This is a picture of my CAD design of a new end effector (OTB no alage intake) that we plan to build. I am designing it with ease of manufacturing and cost in mind, so I am trying to take advantage of 3d printing since this only will see one Offseason comp and doesn’t have to be bulletproof. My question is - how can I power the front horizontal rollers? I have thought of a twisted belt but I have never done that before and need some input from you guys. Another thought was a 3d printed 90 degree gearbox with belts running from motor and then to the shaft. It is not high torque so I am not sure. Any suggestions/tips?

posts.name: Harrison
posts.cooked: Also, those wheels in the front will be replaced with 5 inch star intake wheels to have more contact with the coral (I cut the polycarb plates last night on the CNC already, I wanted to finalize this first but we meet once a week and don’t have a ton of time.) I am open to suggestions for the intake as well, I am hoping to send the laser cut parts to our sponsor by Monday.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
I suspect you can mount a motor back by the main pivot point and do a simple belt reduction, something like a 12:48. The neo will have plenty of power.

Separate question: is there a reason you are using a pair of bros with 99 degree gearboxes on them?

For a design like this I would suspect minimizing weight, especially that mounted away from the pivot, would be a priority.

Skyehawk:

I suspect you can mount a motor back by the main poivit point and do a simple belt reduction.

Absolutely this, polycarb can hold motors plenty fine and hold up to the stresses.

posts.name: Harrison
posts.cooked:
So mainly because:

1: We already had that electrical setup on our previous claw (for a legit reason)

2: I am not super confident with gears. Do you have any tips on how to use the 1 but reverse the direction for the other side of the intake.

If I can achieve #2 , then I can move one of those motors back towards the main pivot and do what you mentioned for the belt.

posts.name: Lachlan
posts.cooked: If you wanted to be even fancier you don’t have to mount the motor to the end effector. You could do something like 1778 crescendo intake where there roller is powered by a motor mounted to their drivetrain

hjmcphail76:

2: I am not super confident with gears. Do you have any tips on how to use the 1 but reverse the direction for the other side of the intake.

With gears they reverse themselves. If you use just two gears that are able to interact with each other (they can probably be 3d printed), they will work correctly. Alternatively, because the distance may be the limiting factor here, use a smaller gear set, then a belt to the existing hex shafts. A twisted belt may work, but if you haven’t experimented with them before it may be risky, I don’t know.

posts.name: Harrison
posts.cooked: When I say I am not confident with gears I mean I have not CADed a robot subsystem that is actually going to be built that uses them and this is hopefully my learning experience.

Well, good a place as any to start from!

There are some Onshape featurescripts than can generate custom gears, we used them 3d printed on our 2023 intake (Wildstang 111), and our 2025 Algae claw mechanism without much of an issue.

This is the gear one I used, but there are plenty that will all do the job just fine

Sign in to Onshape, the #1 fastest growing CAD system in the world with over 4 million users.

posts.name: Harrison
posts.cooked: Do you have a link to that featurescript and/or a picture of the CAD? (edit: I see it now) Again, I have been CADing for about 2 years now and as a smaller team we have kept everything as simple as possible but I want to break from that. My main concern is reliability with them, but I am willing to give it a go!

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
3dp gears will probably work, however I would just use a figure 8 belt here for weight reasons.

I would use 3d printing to play with belt/pulley combos. A printer is an excellent tool for this task.

The reason I say to use a figure 8 here is all you care about is the two vertical rollers (that hold the coral) don’t need to be perfectly in sync, just mostly in sync. So if a belt skips a tooth you are fine.

I would swap those 550s on 90° gearboxes for a single neo to power both of those vertical rollers, and a single neo near the main pivot to power the horizontal shaft with the stara via a long belt and a belt reduction (I would design the motor mount to have a fair bit of adjustment to control belt tension)

Happy to intermittently answer questions throughout the day.

(As an aside, @avanboekel … What have you done, I am now recommending neos and belt reductions everywhere!)

Some notes about our use of the 3d printed gears:

They will chip and experience load, walls and lots of infill are needed to make them work

in 2025 for our Algae mech, we didn’t need to replace them as far as I am aware once over 89 official matches, more practices as well.

In 2023, the same story, although be careful of your clearances, I think we did have an issue where the gears hit a steel plate and shredded a bit.

Keep care with wires. 3d printed gears generally need bigger teeth in order to hold up, making it easier to catch

Or just follow what Skyehawk said, there is a reason he has so many likes.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
FinIce:

there is a reason he has so many like

A sizable chunk of those are memes.

posts.name: Harrison
posts.cooked: How do I determine belt length for this? Any examples?

posts.name: Eric Bergquist
posts.cooked:
For the discussion about 3D printed gears, many teams succeed in 3D-printing gears for lower-toque applications. But honestly, if you have access any two identical and conveniently-sized aluminum gears, I would use those over 3D printed gears.

Luckily, geartrains are super easy to design. There’s really only three things that you need to do to confirm that you geartrain will work. I’ve included a design I made to mimic the 1323 end effector from this year for reference.

C-to-C Distance: To calculate the distance between your 20DP  gears (the most common in FRC ), just use ( #teeth_gear1 + #teeth_gear2 ) / 40 = C-to-C distance in inches. In the example below, roller reversal is done with two 28t gears, so the C-to-C distance is (28+28)/40=1.400”.

Shaft Support: Your hex shaft should have two bearings, and the gear should either be between the bearings (ideal) or just outside one of them. The more you cantilever a gear away from the supporting bearing, the worse it will perform.

Interference: This is just a general design tip, but geartrains can have inconvenient interferences, especially when stringing multiple reductions together. You have to model the entire geartrain and all supporting structures to check for interferences, not just assume you have enough space.

Madtown End Effector 3504×2477 1.24 MB

Madtown End Effector 3504×2477 1.24 MB

Madtown End Effector 3504×2477 1.24 MB

Madtown End Effector (1) 3504×2477 1.64 MB

Madtown End Effector (1) 3504×2477 1.64 MB

Madtown End Effector (1) 3504×2477 1.64 MB

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
So there are a few things to consider to get you close:

path length of the figure 8. This is as you would expect.

path length of the figure 8. This is as you would expect.

because the belt can’t pass through itself there is a 3 dimensional element, albeit minor

because the belt can’t pass through itself there is a 3 dimensional element, albeit minor

using larger pulleys is better here, especially with timing belts, you don’t want the teeth to interlock as the belt rubs on itself as the teeth pass over one another.

using larger pulleys is better here, especially with timing belts, you don’t want the teeth to interlock as the belt rubs on itself as the teeth pass over one another.

I will try to dig up a thread… Give me a second.

Edit: here is a start…

Infinity Timing Belt? General Forum

Infinity Timing Belt? General Forum

… And a reference image

pic: 876 Rockpicker CD-Media: Photos

pic: 876 Rockpicker CD-Media: Photos

As far as designing, I would get a ballpark with cad and then just print a couple pulleys to adjust. E.g., design for 22t pulleys, then print some 20t, 21t, 23t, and 24t. Just play around with a few similar belt lengths and the number of teeth on the pulleys until it behaves.

posts.name: Harrison
posts.cooked: I think you could remove those 90-degree gearboxes and place the NEO 550s on top of each axle. It would be less compact, but you would have more space where the gearboxes currently are to fit a 550 or X44 and run a belt to the front. Also, if you want to save weight, you could replace those 550s with X44’s. It would save a good bit of weight and cost about the same to run.

I can 3dp that mount for it and I will look at that later. Overall, how does this look though? I want to move the motors back more but I think this is a good starting point.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
Looking good, I would put that top motor (that runs the stars) even closer to the pivot. I would also make that motor mount slotted so you can tension the belt easily.

What motor is running the other rollers? A single 550 may not be enough depending on compression. An OG neo may be a good call here, although it only has a stubby 8mm keyed shaft annd you will want the longer hex… Of course there are ways around that

For the figure 8, I would just find the length of the crossed path as a 2d approximation and order that. I would expect to size of the pulleys to come down by about a tooth or two each as a result of reality being 3d
